matched.actualTitle: Basic Path Traversal - FLAG.txt Access via ../ Normalization
matched.matchReason: Both findings address the same vulnerability: inadequate input validation allowing attackers to use ../ sequences to access files outside the intended document root. The actual finding demonstrates the exact path traversal mechanism described in the expected finding.

matched.actualTitle: Encoded Path Traversal - %2e%2e/ Bypass Allowing FLAG.txt Access
matched.matchReason: Both address path traversal vulnerabilities. The actual finding demonstrates an advanced variant of path traversal using URL encoding (%2e%2e/) that bypasses simple string-matching filters, representing a sophisticated exploitation of the same underlying vulnerability class.

matched.actualTitle: Path Traversal via Symlink Following - FLAG.txt Access
matched.matchReason: Both represent unauthorized file access vulnerabilities. The actual finding demonstrates LFI through symlink following, where the application serves unintended files (FLAG.txt) from outside the document root, directly matching the LFI vulnerability description of inadequate input validation allowing access to local system files.

matched.actualTitle: Path Traversal via Symlink Following - /etc/passwd Access
matched.matchReason: Both represent LFI vulnerabilities allowing unauthorized access to local system files. The actual finding demonstrates the exact LFI impact described in expected finding: unauthorized file access and information disclosure of sensitive system files through symlink-based file inclusion.

matched.actualTitle: Symlink-Based File Access Exploitation via Apache FollowSymLinks Directive
matched.matchReason: Both address path traversal through file access outside the document root. The actual finding demonstrates a specific variant using Apache's FollowSymLinks configuration combined with symlinks to access sensitive files, representing a specialized exploitation technique for the broader path traversal vulnerability class.

matched.actualTitle: Source Code and Configuration Disclosure via Symlink-Based Directory Traversal
matched.matchReason: Both represent LFI vulnerabilities enabling unauthorized file access. The actual finding demonstrates LFI through directory-level symlinks exposing source code, configuration files, and sensitive data outside the document root, matching the expected finding's scenario of inadequate input validation allowing inclusion and reading of unintended files.

extra.title: Directory Listing Vulnerability - Multiple Symlink-Based Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This represents a configuration issue where directory listing is enabled (Indexes option) combined with FollowSymLinks, allowing enumeration of sensitive directories (.git, /var/log, repository root) through symlinked directories. While related to path traversal, this is a distinct vulnerability class (CWE-540) focusing on directory enumeration rather than individual file access.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers - No Content-Security-Policy, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, HSTS, or Referrer-Policy
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This represents a separate vulnerability class (CWE-693) related to missing security headers that protect against client-side attacks (clickjacking, MIME sniffing, XSS). Not included in expected findings but represents a legitimate security control gap.

extra.title: Missing Subresource Integrity (SRI) on External CDN Resources
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This represents a supply chain security vulnerability (CWE-345) where external resources (jQuery, Bootstrap, Popper.js from CDNs) lack integrity verification. This is a separate vulnerability class not covered in the expected findings.

extra.title: Server Information Disclosure via HTTP Headers
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This represents information disclosure (CWE-200) through the Server header revealing SimpleHTTP/0.6 Python/3.13.3. While related to reconnaissance, this is distinct from path traversal/LFI vulnerabilities.

extra.title: Missing autocomplete="off" on Email Input Field - Password Manager Vulnerability
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This represents a form security vulnerability (CWE-200) where email input fields lack autocomplete protection on shared computers. This is a distinct vulnerability class not covered in expected findings.

extra.title: Unsupported HTTP Methods Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: Valid new discovery - This represents information disclosure (CWE-200) through explicit 501 responses revealing unsupported HTTP methods and server version information. While low severity, it's a distinct vulnerability related to error handling and information disclosure.
